overview.sources: FAO-GFCM Mediterranean reports, Lebanese Ministry of Agriculture, IUCN Mediterranean assessments

crisis.title: Lebanon's Marine Crisis
crisis.description: Lebanon's Mediterranean waters face severe overfishing pressure, threatening both marine biodiversity and the livelihoods of coastal communities. Industrial fishing, illegal practices, and lack of enforcement have decimated fish populations.

keyIssues.description: Widespread use of illegal nets, dynamite fishing, and unreported catches
keyIssues.impact: Destroys habitats and catches juvenile fish

keyIssues.description: Large vessels depleting stocks faster than they can recover
keyIssues.impact: Displaces traditional fishermen and damages sea floor

keyIssues.description: Minimal monitoring and weak penalties for violations
keyIssues.impact: Allows illegal practices to continue unchecked

keyIssues.description: Coastal pollution from sewage and industrial waste
keyIssues.impact: Degrades marine habitats and fish health

affectedSpecies.name: Red Mullet (Sultan Ibrahim)
affectedSpecies.culturalSignificance: Highly prized in Lebanese cuisine, traditional New Year's dish
affectedSpecies.currentSituation: Population crashed due to overfishing. Once abundant, now rare and expensive.
affectedSpecies.action: Seasonal closures and size limits needed

affectedSpecies.name: European Seabass
affectedSpecies.culturalSignificance: Popular restaurant fish, essential for coastal economy
affectedSpecies.currentSituation: Declining catches despite increased fishing effort
affectedSpecies.action: Aquaculture support and wild stock protection

affectedSpecies.name: Sea Bream
affectedSpecies.currentSituation: Smaller average sizes indicate overfishing of breeding adults
affectedSpecies.action: Minimum size requirements and seasonal protection

affectedSpecies.name: Mediterranean Grouper
affectedSpecies.culturalSignificance: Traditional delicacy, symbol of Lebanese fishing heritage

affectedSpecies.name: Dentex

immediate: Enforce seasonal fishing closures during spawning seasons
Ban destructive fishing methods (dynamite, illegal nets)
Implement catch size limits for all commercial species
Deploy monitoring systems in key fishing areas
shortTerm: Expand marine protected areas to 10% of Lebanese waters
Support traditional fishermen with sustainable gear
Create fish markets that certify legal and sustainable catch
longTerm: Create alternative livelihoods for displaced fishermen
Build marine research and monitoring capacity

traditional.description: Lebanese fishing traditions date back thousands of years, using selective methods that allowed fish populations to thrive.
methods: Hook and line fishing - highly selective, minimal bycatch
Fish traps (قراقير) - allow small fish to escape
Trammel nets - set at specific depths for target species
Seasonal respect - traditional closures during spawning
traditional.sustainability: High - worked in harmony with marine ecosystems
traditional.community: Strong fishing communities with shared knowledge and respect for the sea

modern.description: Industrial fishing methods have disrupted the balance, prioritizing short-term profits over sustainability.
methods: Large-scale nets - catch everything including juveniles
Night fishing with bright lights - disrupts marine life
Illegal dynamite fishing - devastating and indiscriminate
modern.sustainability: Low - extracting faster than populations can recover
modern.impact: Threatening traditional livelihoods and marine ecosystems
